Rudy ‚Ä¢ April 30, 2006 5:29 PM

Of the several terrorist attacks since and including 11 Sep, 2001, the Sep 11 attacks probably had the largest world wide impact. The train bombing in Spain and the tube bombing in London both produced limited results, largely because those were local modes of travel. The Sep 11 hijackings are more an international nature, and it also struck at the world’s sole superpower. There is something inherently more horrific about an air-crash, viz Lockerbie.

Symbolism as well as number of victims both play a part in target selection. So, once more, to strike terror into the world, the terrorists will go back to planes, and their concept of operation will be the simultaneous in-air explosions of multiple US carriers.

Terrorists in groups of 2 or 3 will board flights originating in the US, and with destinations domestically and internationally. The explosives, detonators and fuzes will be carried internally in the same manner that drug mules smuggle their cargo. A ceramic or obsidian blade will also be smuggled aboard.

At the designated time in flight, two terrorists will have to go to the lav together; if they have a third accomplice, he can act as a shield or distraction to prevent other passengers from seeing the other two enter the same lav. In the lav, one of the terrorists will kill the mule; then using the smuggled ceramic blade, must now disembowel the other terrorist in order to retrieve the explosives. Because one can swallow only so much cargo, the explosives will have to be military grade HE, like RDX or PETN. In the bathroom, the bomb is assembled; the terrorist exits the lav, and uses the same ceramic blade to relock the lav from the outside to prevent other people from accidentally discovering the disemboweled terrorist. The bomb will then have to be detonated somewhere vulnerable, probably over the wing box, or in the tail-section.

A sufficiently determined suicide terrorist cannot be stopped. With this action, they have once again showed that they are willing to martyr themselves for their cause, and not even the increased security of the world’s greatest superpower can detect and prevent intentional downings of commercial aircraft, and that there is no where safe for anyone. X-raying shoes are not the answer.

dallendoug ‚Ä¢ April 30, 2006 6:17 PM

I hope this makes it in, it’s kind of at the wire, but it’s been a busy month and I was out of town this weekend. It has elements of several other people’s, but I came up with it before looking through the list, so hopefully I’ll get originality for tying them all together and being more coherent than some . . .

—

It’s 4:15 PM, and Joe Castle was sitting in the DHS Command bunker in downtown Washington DC. The bunker was put in place two years ago, the budget items covered with black marker or simply not existing in some places in the Congressional record. Despite the millions on hardening against NBC threats, super-redundant communication links, and the underground monorail that connected them out to the tunnels that ran between the various congressional buildings and the Library of congress, he still couldn’t get a decent cup of coffee. He thought about ducking out to go to the coffee shop in Union Station, but he didn’t think it was worth the 20 minute trip out, and then the 35 minute trip back in (each checkpoint he pass would a good 3-5 minutes to his trip). Perhaps in the next procedural review he could get an exception for Drinks On Demand, allowing them courier priveleges and putting them on the pre-approved list so he could get a good cup of Java while it was still hot . . . who would question a line item add for a “DOD Courier . . .?”

He gazed across the monitors, a chaotic babble of information from dozens of different feeds — closed circuit of most of the major downtown intersections, the George Washington Univerisity campus cameras, CNN, MSNBC, and several of the local news stations. Other monitors were quieter, but the still poured information to those who watched. . . the latest dumps from AT&T and other ISP’s, courtesy of the NSA, a variety of early warning sensors from around the net and SCADA systems across the country, with large “protected by Cisco” banners flashing on important looking flatscreens when he happened to walk past them and they would look good in a shot.

As he sighed and walked across to the pathetic government instant coffee stand in the corner, his view halted on on monitor that was showing the early early early evening not quite afternoon news on the local Fox channel. He stopped not because of the headlines, the same old same old, more dead in Iraq, more bad things happening locally in society, but because of the moment of recognition when he saw the perfect teeth and purposely blank expression of Tricia Tattler, and felt a pang of regret. He hadn’t seen Tricia in two weeks, since they had finally parted ways — the tension between his having to keep his work secret and her burning desire for a juicy lead had finally pushed them apart. But he still couldn’t help but think of how things could have been in a happier time, so he stopped and watched until the end of the segment.

“That’s all Jim. And now, we’ll go to Bob in our traffic center, for traffic on the eights. Bob, how’s the rush hour shaping up?”

“Well Tricia, if it’s not one thing, it’s another. We have a back up forming on the American Legion Bridge on the outer loop heading in to Virginia due to a disabled truck, which apparently couldn’t make it all the way across, so we’re down a lane with no shoulder, and of course the folks headed back to Maryland are rubbernecking and slowing the flow going the other way. We’re getting reports of another truck broken down on the Wilson bridge as well, more details as we get them. I guess it’s just not a good day for the rental companies. I bet a lot of commuters wish those folks had picked a different day to move. As always, we’ll have another update every 10 minutes until 7 PM, but now to the weather.”

Joe looked at the grainy traffic camera view before the camera popped over to the Hank, the Washington Weather Wizard. He thought sure he could see several other trucks bearing rental company markings on the other side of the Wilson bridge in the rubbernecking . . . did one of them have it’s flashers on? He dropped thoughts of coffee from his mind, and quick-walked over to his console, and began pulling up images from the traffic feeds. While he typed away and clicked with his mouse, he flipped his desk audio through some of the feeds until he got the one he wanted running in the background . . .

“Ten Ten WINS, the most listend to radio station in the country, serving all of New York City, with traffic and weather every ten minutes on the tens. It’s a shaping up to be one heck of a rush hour today . . . someone’s going to get a ticket, but that’s not much comfort — it appears that not one but TWO drivers have chosen to ignore rush hour tunnel restrictions, and now we are looking at gridlock in the Lincoln AND Holland tunnels. I’d hate to be them when the police finally make it there, but that’s not going to help anyone get home faster. The damage has already been done. And, it appears that if you are trying to head out the other side of the city, you’re out of luck there too there’s a snarl developing on the Brooklyn Bridge, a minor accident between several cars and a mid-sized container truck have brought things to a standstill, and there is major backup on the BQE heading towards Staten Island, due to a disabled vehicle on the lower span — we haven’t been able to get a good look in there, so cell callers, if you are stuck that neighborhood, give us a ring and let us know what’s going on. Up at the George Washington Bridge, again on the lower span, there is some type of impasse, details as we get them. But really folks, this might be a good time to hit that happy hour and try again in a few hours. At least the subway’s running fine . . .”

Joe had pulled up the NYMTA feeds on the bridges in question, and looked at similar scenes to those in DC . . . Penske here, Ryder there, Uhaul for one or two, but in each case, he was looking at different flavors of rental container trucks sitting parked or wrecked on major bottlenecks . . . all bridges. He began to feel the pit of his stomach drop down to where his toes were, if he could feel them through the growing cold that was enveloping his body. He scrambled for the speeddials on his phone — the damn things hadn’t been programmed properly yet, and he managed after a few rings to get “Welcome to Audix. To set up your voice mailbox, please press pound.”

He clicked to a new line, and dialed his buddy Rick up in NYC from memory. The phone rang as he pulled up Baltimore, and then Boston. The phone clicked.

“Rick –”

“Hi, this is Rick MaJeure of the DHS, NYC field office. I’m not at my desk right now, but if you would like to leave a message . . . ”

Joe swore in frustration, and hung up. The phone rung almost immediately, and he looked — no Caller ID available. What the heck, he thought? Aren’t we the DHS? Can’t we get decent caller ID? He punched over to that line.

“To set up your normal busy greeting, press one. To set up your away greeting, press two. To set up an extended absence greeting, press three . . .” With a howl of annoyance, Joe slammed down the phone on the automated voice. Of course! He had Rick’s cell phone number in his cell . . . he pulled out his Razr and flipped it open, and then remembered he was in the bunker. No signal down here, except for DHS approved CO-OP devices, which there was a relay for. His personal cell wasn’t on it. He flipped to Rick’s entry, and began punching it into the desk phone, and turned his gaze back to the monitors. He was on the next two digits past the 212 area code when he froze. One by one, the monitors were going a bright, bright white, and then nothing. . .

Ten minutes later, as DHS staff and military attaches ran through the bunker, orders were shouted, and everyone seemed to be talking and trying to do things at once, a variety of empty screens still glared from the traffic monitoring sections. In one or two cases, news feeds showed shaky chopper shots from a distance, showing plumes of smoke rising from the thin, shattered shapes of bridges off in the distance, as the news choppers observed no-fly zones while getting in as close to the story as possible. Joe’s phone rang again, and he snapped it up reflexively, only then looking at the display. Crud!! — it was Tricia, and he had picked it up.

“Joe?”

“Tricia, this is NOT a good time.”

“Joe, what’s going on?”

“Trish, look, really, I’ll tell you as soon as we can tell anyone. You know I can’t give you any more than that, and I sure as hell am not going to speculate.”

“Dangit Joe, this isn’t about work, I’m scared. Look, I’ll trade — I have information for YOU. I’ll tell you what I know, and maybe it will help everyone out. Joe, people in the streets are going crazy. We’ve got our “men on the street” types downstairs, and people are saying there’s been some sort of an attack, and there’s no way out of the city.”

“Well, there may be some routes that have been impaired. We’re looking in to that. But you and I know that already.”

“But that’s not just it Joe. Joe, we’re getting call after call, saying that people are acting strangely, that something else is going on. We’ve had callers from Dupont Circle and Federal Center saying that people are running around, foaming from the mouths. Some people appear to have collapse, and there are people running everywhere. We just got a call in from someone at L’Enfant saying that some man had walked into the Mall there, and was spraying an aeresol can around, and that people near him started coughing and choking and running away. And now . . . hold on . . . Pete is saying that we’re getting similar reports from Times Square and the financial district, near Wall Street in New York.”

Joe didn’t think his stomach could get any tighter or lower. But suddenly he was fighting to keep his bowels in his body, literally and figuratively as fear gripped him and twisted deep inside.

“Trish, listen to me,” Joe intoned, trying to stay calm. “Stay there, stay inside, keep your co-workers inside and try to shut off the building, or at least your part. There may be some sort of bioweapons at work. Please, stay on the line, for god’s sake, don’t put this on the air right away — I’ll try to get you everything I can, but just stay there and stay put, OK?”

“Trish? Trish, are you there . . . ?”

Will the United States survive? Will Joe find Trish in the ashes of DC? Will the horrors of terrorism show them the value of the important things in life, so that they can put aside their differences and live together happily in the bunker as riots continue unabated outside, as shipping routes for ground transport are disrupted and the american press and public spend a week ironing out what really is going on and what is only hysteria? And, most important of all, will Joe ever find a truly great cup of coffee? Coming to local theatres next spring, be on the lookout for “One Mean Cup of Joe . . .”

Assume the maxes here — 30 terrorists, and the best budget you can do ($500,000). I’m also assuming communication and coordination per person is built in to my costs.

Part I — the “trucks with fertilizer” (or the like)

Detail 20 terrorists to do the truck thing — stagger everything possible to avoid any DHS/NSA/other agency automated scanning/reporting tools looking for suspicious activity.

explosives creation through a variety of high-yield methods, different things mixed up around the country -- some fertilizer, some stolen industrial, some black-market, whatever you can get) -- assume average of $10,000/vehicle for everything *20 = $200,000

truck rentals through a variety of companies, all for a week or two week rental, starting at different dates to the rentals do not appear uniform. Terrorists should still be able to garner fake credentials easily, or, for those with clean records, just rent in their own names and credit lines (albeit separated from any transactions that might tie in on the explosives side. -- assume average of $1500 for 20' truck for a week * 20 = $30,000

traffic incidents -- timing is somewhat essential, but not pinpoint -- once evening rush hour has started, ground response times are going to suck in most locations. Fake accidents (or minor accidents) or breakdowns can be staged/created so that people who are running ahead are in time -- you could even detail a few terrorists to other vehicles other than the trucks depending on what your target list is. But rush hour is free. This plan is mainly focused on the east coast, due to proximity and population density concerns -- so you would want it in the middle or slightly earlier in the East Coast rush hour, so that the maximum confusion without any chance for advance planning would take place (with most people still needing to leave the city). -- free

There's also a bridge East of chicago that goes through a quarry, is under construction, and seems to carry 90% of the truck traffic going to Chicago from Indiana these days

You could widen the campaign across the country and lessen the impact . . . unless you had a higher budget (or, considering my numbers are probably way high, you could probably squeeze out a bunch more truck bombs than what I detailed).

The goal of the “truck thing” in this manner is to sever road arteries — may US cities have a limited number bridge crosssings, and many of them are including vital interstates. The initial terror and dischord will then be followed by crippling long-term traffic and shipping problems for the cities and ports involved — sever the main bridges, and New York, Baltimore, and DC are all in an immense amount of traffic pain for potentially YEARS while they scramble to rebuild (see the current DC Wilson Bridge project and mixing bowl, and how long they are taking to progress).

Then, Part II . . .

Biowarfare and misinformation — this is the other key part of the plan . . . sow terror, through any means neccessary. Once gunshy cities are reminded of 9/11 again in a frightening burst of deja vu, people will see similarities to the first time around — fueled by the terrorists. After the explosions and transportation issues have been set in motion, the remaining terrorists could strike through information only . . . but if budget allowed, a small level, highly visible public toxin attack in the affected cities could be grounds for HUGE panic, if it is followed up effectively with enough disinformation. Let’s take 4 of our remaining terrorists, and set them up in isolated locations with high-speed connections, decent computers, skype-out/yahoo voice/other VOIP-landline services, and have them start hitting every news source they can think of — call in to 911, tip lines, traffic report lines, police watch lines, etc . . . if well prepared, one terrorist could simultaneously unleash dozens of calls, and then trigger pre-recorded audio cues of distressed citizens wailing about the panic and horrible things in the background, without really needing any actual interaction, and then dropping the connection, possibly with the implication of something horrible happening to the caller. Let say a whopping $10,000 to outfit each of these guys (way more than needed, but what the hey) — $40,000

That takes us up to $270,000 so far and 6 terrorists remaining. I’m guessing with some time to work on it, with almost $40,000 per person, you could dig up some decent fear-inducing bioweapons or toxins. They don’t even have to be fatal, they just have to scare the heck out of people, and cause doubt in the infrastructure and cause weeks or months of clean-up work. A few anthrax-laden letters shutdown a post office in DC for YEARS, not just a few weeks. So, 6 * $38,333 per = $230,000.

Obviously, I am not an explosives expert, the size of trucks and amount of charges and cost might need to be tweaked, but there is tons of headroom in this plan to juggle the numbers. And, if you scaled down the vehicle targets, that too makes for more freedom in the bottom line. The real damage is going to be caused by the normal daily routine of all these cities and this country’s citizens trying to complete their daily routine in a panic, and then the painful, long, extended cleanup that has to follow . . .

so — total cost of $500,000

regular US city commuting snafu — free

Otario ‚Ä¢ April 30, 2006 8:43 PM 

The attacks began midmorning on the Friday after Thanksgiving. Thirty minutes after a large regional mall in rural South Carolina opened for its traditional after-Thanksgiving sale, a bomb exploded in the center atrium. Placed at the bottom of a trash receptacle, the bomb consisted of nothing more than a timer, a blasting cap, and dynamite, covered with 30 pounds of ball bearings. The explosion shattered most of the plate-glass display windows and sent shrapnel flying in all directions. Over 400 people were killed instantly and well over a thousand‚Äîthere were too many for a precise count‚Äîwere wounded.

A television crew sent to interview shoppers about the sale was standing just inside the west entrance and was broadcasting live to the local morning talk show when the bomb detonated. The blast tore off most of the reporter‚Äôs right arm and decapitated the woman she was interviewing, as the inevitable slow-motion replays later demonstrated. The camera crew, shielded from the blast by a concrete pillar, escaped serious injury and continued to broadcast unedited pictures of the slaughter. An alert staffer at the television station notified the network, and less than five minutes after the explosion, the national audience was viewing live pictures of bloodied shoppers stumbling and crawling toward the exits.

The local emergency plan, designed to cover floods and hurricanes, never anticipated having to treat so many seriously injured people at the same time. Doctors and paramedics who rushed to the scene were overwhelmed by the scale of the carnage. The nearest hospital was more than 20 minutes away, no available transportation could move hundreds of wounded at a time, and the hospital had only 30 beds and no trauma center. Consequently, the medical teams treated the wounded in the parking lot, inadequately equipped with supplies scavenged from the Wal-Mart across the street and nearby drug stores. By noon, the television cameras could no longer avoid showing the growing pile of severed arms and legs as doctors gave up all hope of reconstructing the shattered limbs of the victims. Even with industrial-scale amputations, the medical teams could not possibly deal with all of the injured, and more than half of them died before they could be treated. Their bodies were stacked in the far corner of the parking lot and incinerated with borrowed gasoline as darkness fell. 

Within an hour of the South Carolina explosion, a dozen similar attacks on regional malls and shopping centers were confirmed as viewers watched footage arriving from such disparate places as western Massachusetts, upstate New York, central Pennsylvania, tidewater Virginia, and northern Alabama. It appeared at first that the large cities had been spared, since new reports from the Midwest were coming from rural Ohio, southern Indiana, central Iowa, and northeastern Missouri. Then a news flash from Chicago announced that the first floor of the city‚Äôs largest downtown department store had been hit by at least three explosions that caused a partial collapse of the second and third floors. Estimates of the number of dead and wounded were not immediately available. 

As new bombs popped up on colorful television maps, the western movement of the attacks became obvious. By the time the President addressed the nation from the White House at noon and called for calm, shopping centers throughout the country were ghost towns. Most of the employees of the stores fled with the customers, leaving their supervisors wondering how to recoup the losses of what should have been the biggest sales day of the year. 

Rural police and fire departments were uncomfortably aware all of the attacks except the Chicago bombing were taking place in jurisdictions like theirs, and they searched for bombs as best they could. But they had no experience in finding or disarming explosives, despite having accepted billions of dollars in grants from the Department of Homeland Security for training their personnel to respond to terrorist attacks. Only in central Nebraska did a sheriff‚Äôs deputy manage to find and disarm one of the devices before it detonated, and she admitted that discovering it was pure dumb luck.

With the malls evacuated, the 10 attacks west of the Mississippi River caused mainly property damage. They produced only 31 deaths‚Äî23 employees of the stores and malls, 3 police officers, and 5 firefighters. 

By sunset on Friday, 27 malls had been bombed. Except for the Chicago department store, all the attacks struck regional malls in rural areas. Nearly 10,000 people were dead; no one knew how many were wounded. The number of deaths kept increasing as emergency care facilities were overwhelmed and unable to treat all the wounded.

One reporter tried to put the losses in perspective by observing that over the next year, more Americans would be killed by drunk drivers than were killed in the mall bombings. The media‚Äôs attention was diverted briefly from its round-the-clock coverage of the attacks as commentators and pundits excoriated the hapless reporter. Within two hours his network pulled him from their lineup. 

By Saturday, television stations had preempted all programs and were running nothing but news without commercial breaks. However, with nothing new happening, the air time was filled with updates on the overloaded medical facilities near the bombing sites, endless videos of the dead and dying, and commentary by pundits who turned out to know little about terrorism.

The pressing need to fill broadcast time led to some bizarre episodes. The Commerce Secretary urged Americans to return to their local malls and spend as much as they could to make up for the business losses of Friday. One commentator suggested a nuclear attack on France. Religious leaders who had gleefully argued that the 9/11 attacks on New York and Washington were evidence of divine retribution for urban wickedness eagerly appeared for interviews but proved reluctant when asked to explain why terror had come to the heartland.

On Sunday, a new wave of bombings struck gas stations across the country between midnight and dawn. In all, 287 stations were hit, all located in middle-class and upper-income bedroom communities. Many of the fires caused by the explosions spread to nearby residential areas, destroying thousands of homes and killing 95 firefighters and over 2,500 others.

The gas station bombings cut the usually heavy traffic of Thanksgiving Sunday by more than two-thirds. Many people refused to travel, imagining that they might be blown up as they fueled their cars. More than 30% of the American workforce failed to report for work on Monday morning, though no one was sure how much of that was directly linked to people who did not return home on Sunday.

Investigations showed how easy it was to attack the gas stations. All 287 stations were closed on Saturday evening. The terrorists simply drove up, dropped their bombs in the trash cans next to the pumps, and drove off without alarming anyone or even attracting attention. A single terrorist could easily have delivered 10 or 15 bombs in a 40-mile radius in just a few hours.

On Monday morning, stores began opening for the first time since Friday. Most shoppers stayed away from malls and downtown shopping areas, and there were no lines at gas stations. By contrast, grocery stores were jammed with customers who apparently felt safe in their local markets. Shortly after noon Eastern Standard Time, sixty-one bombs exploded in supermarkets in the 20 largest American cities. Two bombs that failed to explode were discovered late Monday in Denver, each a simple dynamite bomb buried deep in the frozen food section sealed in a plastic bag that had contained Brussels sprouts.

Fewer people died on Monday morning than were killed in the Friday mall attacks, Even so, almost 1,200 people were killed and more injured, many of whom were trampled as shoppers stampeded out of the markets.

The immediate effect of the attacks was that Americans were afraid to leave home, and they shunned retail businesses. People were wary of going anywhere that had crowds or that might be a target of a bomb. Gas stations reported most people pumped only a few gallons of gas into their cars before speeding away. (Highway statistics showed that the number of traffic accidents, which had been decreasing for years, rose sharply after the Thanksgiving attacks. Statisticians attributed most of the increase to nervous drivers eager to escape from harm's way.) Retail businesses started to fail and unemployment rose quickly.

For weeks, no one claimed credit for the attacks. The government was unable to discover who the attackers were, or whether they were foreign or domestic. And then, on December 21, the terrorists released a communiqu√© revealing that the bombings were carried out by 28 individuals spending less than $500,000. The communiqu√© never specified the reasons for the attacks; its tedious and ambiguous political diatribe led conspiracy theorists to blame everyone imaginable: the Israelis, the British Queen, the Catholic Church, the Environmental Liberation Front, Sufi mystics, the Dalai Lama, even the Paraguayans. 

Of greater interest was the terrorists‚Äô description of exactly how they carried out the attacks with so little money and so few people. They recruited disaffected members from their communities based on two criteria: ability to learn another language, and a physical appearance that Americans would be likely to mistake for Hispanic. (Later intelligence revealed that about a third of the terrorists were light-skinned and went to tanning salons or used tanning products to darken their skin tones to resemble more closely the American stereotype of the working-class Hispanic.) Before the terrorists entered the United States, they attended language schools in Mexico and Guatemala and learned enough Spanish to pass as Mexicans or Central Americans. Once they were in the United States, it was easy to obtain fake IDs and green cards in the larger metropolitan areas. Cleaning services in malls were only too happy to hire apparent Hispanics willing to work at the minimum wage and without benefits or complaints. (This statement led intelligence officials to theorize that the attackers had placed their bombs in supermarkets on Monday morning while posing as shoppers.)

Looking like Hispanic janitors, the terrorists drew no attention in the malls and had no problem planting their bombs, which had been easily assembled from readily-available materials with very little technical training. The communiqu√© boasted that the attack team had learned how to assemble and arm the dynamite bombs in a single weekend.

It is unclear whether the terrorists intended to use their communiqu√© to hammer a socioeconomic wedge into America, but that was certainly its effect. Many non-Hispanic Americans announced their suspicions of all Hispanics, whether illegal or not, even though nobody could describe who was a Hispanic and who wasn‚Äôt, or how to recognize one. Race riots became commonplace as gangs of vigilantes punished those they suspected as possible terrorists. With law and order breaking down and the economy heading south, the President considered imposing martial law, but the Middle Eastern wars had decimated the National Guard, and the U.S. Army was spread too thin by its overseas commitments to offer much help. 

One insurance company after another announced that its policies did not cover terrorist attacks. There would be no insurance money for rebuilding the malls or for replacing the homes burned in the fires. For those killed who were lucky enough to have life insurance, two-thirds of the policies did not cover death by terrorism. 

On a cold morning in February, the President attended a ceremony at the site of the South Carolina mall to honor the dead and wounded. The mall had stood empty since the day after Thanksgiving. None of the insurance companies would pay for the damage from the attack because of the terrorism exclusion in their policies; none of the owners or tenants had enough money for repairs; no investor wanted to take on the task of cleansing the blood that had stained the walls and floors; and no government funds were available to restore the mall. 

When he agreed to speak, the President hoped his words would give inspiration and hope and comfort. But political and economic realities forced him to devote most of his speech to defending his policies on rapidly rising unemployment and the skyrocketing cost of imports‚Äîespecially oil‚Äîthat accompanied the collapse of the dollar on international money markets. It was hard to decide which was more melancholy: his words, or the ruined shopping mall 200 yards in back of him.

Following the President‚Äôs speech, and after a long and very Protestant prayer by a local minister, the President‚Äôs wife stepped up to the podium and touched two thick cables to an automobile battery. Within seconds, carefully-placed explosive charges reduced the mall to a mound of rubble.

“Communication Breakdown”
Summary: evildoers launch a well coordinated attack to cause massive, lasting disruptions in

communications and also facilitate economic division between the US and foreign countries.

The 30 terrorists break into smaller groups of 3-5 each in order to divide and conquer.

Step 1) Create an environment of fear, uncertainty, and doubt:
Terrorist contact black market spammers and pay them to deliver their message via spam. In short,

the message reads “We will take away your Internet – Remember 9-11-2008!” (with further

embellishment to promote their cause and to attract recruits, and so on…) There’s no virus,

spyware, or tracking in the message, but the message makes people worry. The message gets delivered

(and read) in the majority of American homes, and the flurry of news reports about the “terrorist

spam” spread the word to everyone else.

9/11/2008 arrives with much anticipation, but passes without incident. As time passes, people

forget about the threat. The 11/2008 election arrives with much security and much attention to

computerized voting, but again, passes without (terrorist induced) incident.

Step 2) The coordinated attack:
11/9/2008 – almost immediately after the next presidential election
Morning: Terrorist attack the Internet interconnect points. Much to everyone’s surprise, it is a

physical attack, not a software attack. They target locations where the Internet is physically most

vulnerable. The primary targets are the MAE facilities, the major interconnect point for the

Internet: MAE East in Washington DC (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAE-East), MAE West, other major

interconnect points across the country, etc. Other targets could include (all of) the primary DNS

servers, … (you get the idea – the list goes on and is too easy to make.) Note that not only are

the interconnections broken, but the equipment that did so is now vaporized. Where possible, the

terrorist use a dirty bomb (a terror clich√©, but it works here!) so that it is not possible to

redeploy equipment in the effected area. It takes months to deploy new fiber and create new

interconnects. (Yes, Internet traffic can take a different route on the network, but the alternate

routes don’t have the capacity to handle all of the redirected traffic and become instantly

overloaded.) Then “newsworthyness” of the event only adds to the complications, and the Internet

(in the US, at least) grinds to a halt. The body count is anywhere from 50-200 per bombing,

depending on the facility and bomb size.

Afternoon: Terrorists isolate the US from international communications
A few of the small 3 person terrorist micro-cells trained in scuba and buy/steal small fishing

boats. They travel 10 miles offshore where they cut trans-oceanic telecommunications lines in the

Atlantic and Pacific. They tow one end of the fiber to “parts unknown” so that it can’t be easily

reparied. Communications overseas is still possible, but highly disrupted. The surviving

trans-oceanic lines are so overloaded, they aren’t usable.

Within 24 hours: Disruption of US dependence on international commerce
A couple of the micro-cells work outside of the US. They bomb several key processor chip

manufacturing facilities in Asia. Hundreds of workers are added to the body count. Computers and

other devices which rely on the chips cannot be manufactured for many months, making a long term

impact to the communication disruption. Again, use your imagination.

Step 3) The impact:
People mistakenly attribute “normal” computer/internet problems to “new” terrorist activity

(terrorist hacked my computer again!) When computer/Internet problems arise, terrorism is in the

back of people’s minds as the cause. DHS forms a special internet security subdepartment, and much

personal freedom/privacy on the Internet is given up in the name of security. Much time and money

is diverted into Internet security in preparation for an attack (think pre Y2K hype). Internet

security becomes a minor election year topic.

Internet communications across the US and internationally is significantly disrupted, and the impact

has a ripple effect on all of the economies that rely on it. People quickly notice the impact

because of lack of connectivity to their call centers which are now overseas. Many businesses,

including medical teleradiology (which is frequently outsourced, especially in at night) are greatly

impacted. For brevity, I’ll leave the rest of this to the imagination, but the impact is huge.

The policy of the new Presidential administration focuses on the attack, and how to prevent the same

attack from happening again. Many other areas that need the government’s attention are neglected in

the meantime.

International communication is significantly disrupted, further driving a wedge between the US and

the rest of the world. Others learn not to rely as much on the US for the Internet. Billions are spent on security to protect and physically monitor the trans-oceanic lines (even though terrorist would move on to a new target next time.)

Conclusion:
There is no conclusion. Citizens of the US are left with a hollow, vulnerable feeling knowing how

much of their economy and way of life depend on fragile ties to the rest of the world. The economic

ripple is felt for years to come.

The rules: 20 to 30 people and $500.000

Since the resources are restricted, we need to think of attacks that are very easy to execute yet have a long impact. I don’t deny the effect of a big all out attack, but the sniper in Washington seemed to do a really good job too.

First, we’ll divide the 30 people into several groups.

Group 1: 12 people spread across 6 major US cities. This group will inject random food and drinks in the big supermarkets with a lethal poison. People might mistake it for accidents at first, but as the attacks go on, they won’t. This is also where group 2 comes in.

Group 2: 2 people will be the propaganda team. They will write letters to the city council of target cities of group 1 and the press stating specifically that they are targetting those cities and it’s citizens and that everyone in those cities is at risk. They will also state that more attacks will follow and that they will get worse. After a few weeks, enter Group 3.

Group 3: 8 people will spread to the 8 different major cities to snipe it’s citizens. Group 2 will again inform the media.

Group 4: the remaining 8 people start going to work as arsonists. They will work co-ordinated, meaning that they will set ablaze several different homes at opposite sides in the same city at the same time so that firefighters become overwhelmed. They will repeat this in different major cities throughout the US.

This result will not cause 3000 victims at once but it will create chaos. It will attack the familiar and safe environments of the targets. People will no longer trust the food and drinks they buy. People will no longer dare to walk the streets and people will no longer dare to go to sleep due to fires set to homes. This will cause tremendous stress on the population and it’s productivity. It might also cause (racial) riots etc, Group 2 (the ‘pr’ team could help start these).

Due to the spread-out nature and the low-techness of the attacks law enforcement and intelligence agencies will effectively have a very low chance of making any arrests soon, so the stretch of the attacks is at least a month in my opinion (this can be influenced by measures such as martial law and curfews, at which point all groups would immediately cease their activities, only to resume them as soon as those measures are lifted again).

Due to the longer period during which these attacks can continue, they are more likely to cause the population to become burned-out and extremely tired and stressed than to cause defiance with the population, especially when the authorities seem relatively powerless to stop them.

David Cruz-Uribe, SFO ‚Ä¢ May 15, 2006 8:37 AM

Since the recent Cryptogram said I can ignore the April 30 deadline, here is my contribution to the string of terrorist plots. It encapsulates pieces of many previous ideas, but the (new?) idea is to leverage one terrorist attack off the other.

Divide your strike group of 30 terrorists: one group of 20 and a second group, UNKNOWN to the first, of 10. Group A, which thinks it is THE terrorist group, is split into small cells (3-4). Each cell is tasked with attacking government officials in small and midsized towns: city council meetings, mayors, town managers, public works directors, etc. Accomplishing this would require only publically available data and easily available weapons. In my town, for instance, if there is any security for a town council meeting, it consists of one off-duty police officer. It would be very easy to scout the location, show up at the meeting, kill and wound dozens, and then leave. If the targets were widely scattered, it would be impossible to predict where they would strike.

The power of these attacks is three-fold. First, these are very soft targets. It will be easy to pull off a number of attacks before security is tightened. And even if security is tightened, a simple variation in types of attacks (e.g. shifting from attacks on public meetings to attacks in private homes) will keep the new security from being effective.

Second, it has a very high panic factor because it strikes at the “heartland.” After the anthrax attacks in DC, there were panicked reports of anthrax all over the place, including many in small towns. Should attacks actually occur in small towns, this panic factor would be multiplied many times.

The third feature of these attacks is that they are a deliberate distraction. These attacks would generate a LOT of media attention, and would put pressure on the government to respond. A temporary but large shift in security forces would occur; literally, the government would be looking the other way when the “real” attack occurs.

Group B, which is not known to Group A and is operationally separate, is tasked with planning an attack against a single, high profile ECONOMIC target, say the NYSE or the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. These targets are currently guarded, and a spate of attacks would cause some heightened security. However, since all the group A attacks are against public sector targets in small and medium towns, there would be a tendency to expect the pattern to continue. Thus, police in Chicago could well be pulled off the Mercantile Exchange and shifted to City Hall.

The Group B attack, if successful, would have major reprecussions. First, it would have a significant economic impact. The closure of the Mercantile Exchange for even a few days would have a powerful negative impact on all the world markets. Second, the terror factor would be multiplied because we would be blind-sided. Having been conditioned to expect public-sector attacks (or even having experienced relief when one or more cells from Group A is caught), a new attack in a different sector would be that much more powerful: no one would know where to expect the next attack, and so people would be blindly preparing for every possible attack.

Everything to build a powerful bomb can be bought at Walmart:

  • a large gas can from the auto department
  • 10-15 bottles of “octane booster” fluid from the auto department
  • a bag of nitro fertilizer from the garden department
  • gunpowder from a few hunting rifle cartridges for a fuse
  • a cell phone to be modified into a trigger

Teams of 2 people get into rented vehicles and cruise through the Midwest, stopping at every WalMart they see, purchasing materials locally and leaving the bomb inside the store. The bomb has to look inconspicuous (e.g. a gas can hidden among 50 other gas cans in the auto isle).

With some training, 2-3 bombs can be done in a day by each team, or 40-60 bombs a day by the entire group. Nearly every discount store (not just WalMart, that would be unfair) in an enire state can be targeted within a week.

Then, bombs are triggered in waves using cell phone triggers – the first one looks like “some kids fooling around”, then comes half a dozen “copycats”, and then wave after wave of bombs – until all installations have been either “used” or found.

Stores will institute security checkpoints – but they will be useless because all materials came from inside the store. This point would then be driven home by making a few more bombs.

The “beauty” of this approach is that, despite probably very low casualties (most likely, less then one per bombing), this will likely collapse a very large corporation and potentially destroy the entire industry of large discount stores.

Most impoprtantly, doing this in the Midwest will collapse the idea that terrorism happens in New York and Washington, and instead bring it home to West Podunk, Indiana and every other small town.

This, of course, should be coupled with a slew of neo-fascist candidates running for Congress, local elections and maybe even President. Platform of the neo-fascist party would consist of blaming the terror on certain nations (most likely Arabs and Jews), and would find support in the already conservative rural Midwestern electorate.

The foundations of a fascist regime are already implemented. Total surveillance, detentions without due process, torture and “extraordinary renditions” are already par for the course and accepted by Americans. Only a single trigger event like the one I described could plunge the country into the world of concentration camps and gas chambers. It’s been done before.

So many possibilities… One idea I came up with a few years ago was prompted not by terrorism, but by watching the response of police to a shooting. A man shot at a police car (not actually injuring anyone – though not for lack of trying), and what seemed like every policeman in the metro area converged to take care of the threat.

My thought was how easy it would be to rob a bank at that point.

Similarly – what a great distractor to allow the real attack:

Step 1) sniper teams draw police response by simply shooting at police cars at long range (not necessarily trying to hit the occupants, in fact – preferably allowing them to call in the response!)
Step 2) the teams disengage by leapfrogging out of the area – the first time this technique is used, the police will assume a single sniper rather than multiple supporting teams.
Step 3) once the news media pick this up, several attacks can then occur simultaneously – the best bet would be to focus on one or two high priority targets to be taken out with bombs.
(lacking any particular target – other teams can randomly shoot at individuals – but I think of that as a much lower payoff in terror).
Step 4) have your public relations machine pump out letters to the editor and call-ins to radio and TV shows about how the police car more about themselves than about protecting ‘us’.
Step 5) repeat as necessary.

Note- you need perhaps 8 people per metropolitan area to make this happen, and I would expect it to work best in a medium-sized city (250,000 – 3,000,000 people). Much larger, and your teams will not distract enough of the police force. Much smaller and there’s no real high-payoff target – your groups are also more noticable in a smaller city).

4 random places to hit on the same day, then pick another 4 cities at random and do it again. The third time, work a different scenario.

Tim Sharpe ‚Ä¢ May 15, 2006 3:28 PM

I think an effective plot would be to randomly introduce very deadly toxins to water supplies around the country, particularly in small towns where municipal wells are used. A fairly small group of people could contaminate a small percentage of water suppplies over a large geographic area with relative ease.

Groups of innocent civilians (maybe tens or hundreds at a time) die here and there around the country within a fairly short time (maybe a week or two) from toxins that are easily traced to their water supply.

The media would immediately get wind and the 24-hour news media would whoop it up big. Within a few weeks, authorities would start tightening security at water sources and facilities, but by then the damage would be done.

Across the country, people would fear that their own water was dangerous (just as they fear crime in their own neighborhood based on news reports of crime elsewhere) and panic would break out.

The attack might continue, but once people lost faith in the safety of their water supplies, survivalism would take over and communities would break down as everyone tried to insure their own supply of water. A small number of further contaminations here and there over the next few weeks/months could cause dire economic problems and perhaps cause societal collapse.

Sometime in June, 1976 I was having as beer in the Poplar Place (a watering hole in Moab, Utah) when a table full of “hippies” started fantasizing about celebrating the the 200th anniversary of the American revolution with another one…

Most of them were thinking in terms of blowing up the Glen Canyon Dam (a hot topic about that time, Edward Abbey’s ‘The Monkey Wrench Gang’ had just hit the GreenPeace best sellers list”

Then, a well oiled guy at the bar swung around and, claiming to be a power systems engineer, said, “That wouldn’t do much to most of the country. If you want to sock it to the USA, you need to do the following:

There’s public document published by the Commerce Department called ‘The Atlas of The United States’ that is in most public libraries. Get a copy of and go to the map of the electrical power grid. It shows the rough location of the transport lines of country’s power distribution system weighted by capacity. Do a little math and you’ll see that over 1/3 of the nation’s power crosses the western continental divide at ~17 points.

If you really want to mess things up economically for America –

build some mortars that can lob a good sized piece of chain over a highline,

practice up on how to aim them,

build them with a fairly accurate timer that can run for a week or so and set them off within 30 seconds of each other,

backpack them into the bushes up on the divide,

pick a time sometime in the middle of the summer (say, July 4th) for them to do their thing,

and,

BOOM! out go te lights, except with a twist. There is a HUGE amount of power stored in the electromagnetic fields surrounding transport power lines when they are operating at high capacity and when the current flow suddenly halts, the fields collapse and it’s all injected back into the grid. Whithout something to stop it, it’s injected back into the generators at the power plants. … it would effectively convert the generators into motors that were trying to turn against the rotation of their power sources…)

There are elaborate switching systems in place to protect the whole system from these effects but they are designed to cope with a certain probability of event.

If you sever the lines that carry 1/3 of the nation’s power in the same 30-second interval the event will fall WAY outside the designed capability of the protection systems and a significant fraction of the nation’s power generating machinery would be destroyed.

You will have destroyed much of the critical resource that would be required to manufacture the replacements needed to recover from the event itself.

That would REALLY screw things up!”

Anonymous ‚Ä¢ May 15, 2006 6:38 PM

Low tech, low budget range

This only requires one person with lots of time and some entry capital, say half a million dollars, or just take out a new business loan at the local bank. The terrorist even has a decent chance to get away after the attack.

In the same vein as the Oklahoma Federal Building bombing or the Great Texas City Fertilizer Plant Disaster . You simply go to Crawford Texas or any town that high poliitical figures may frequent and under a false identity, you build or buy the seed and fertilizer store and warehouse. You comply with all the regulations and you run the store like any other rural services place. You hire employees and file your taxes and make friends and enemies in the town like anyone else. You marry a local lass and may even have children.

But you hook up the agricultural diesel supply tanks to the fire sprinkler system over the fertilize storage racks where there are tons and tons of ammonium nitrate and install the requisite catalyst explosives underneath locked plates installled in the floors for apparently good reasons, like support sockets for temporary uprights. Then you wait very patiently.

When the intended victim or victims are within range, you trip the trap by any easily available remote control device like a cell phone and take advantage of the hour or so of sheer chaos to get as far away as possible.

In my movie, the terrorist trips the trap from a small airplane from which he is spotting his victims and is himself knocked out of the air in the blast. Thus there’s even a bit of vengeance from the audience’s point of view….

Two small craft were really knocked down in the Texas City blast of 1947, where the range of damage reached around 15 miles, using some 2300 tons of ammonium nitrate.

Note that all components are legal and readilly available and that you probably don’t even need to invest your own money. You might even earn money while you’re doing the waiting. Most people with a minimum of business sense and common abilities with electonics devices would be able to carry out the plan.

Scott H ‚Ä¢ May 16, 2006 12:21 AM

9/11 Part Deux –

It seems most of the ideas work on creating a “big bang”, for lack of a better term. I see the opportunity for a heavy character development theme. While a few of the pieces have been mentioned before, I haven’t seen them all drawn together.

Recreate basic events of 9/11 – a small group trains for a specialized task to carry out four coordinated attacks. The bad guys boast of the recreating the successes of 9/11 using the same model.

The groups trains for and infiltrates the merchant marine (nationality is unimportant). Points of attack are the Malacca Straits (as described in Dangerous Waters by John Burnett); the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port (LOOP)/Port Fourchon; the Panama Canal; and the Suez Canal.

It’s only necessary to land one or two entry level crew members per ship over the period of a year. Just as with 9/11, wait for the right environment (all the ships in the right spots at the same time), then execute. The goal is to severely damage the targets. One ship would need to be an oil tanker making a port of call at LOOP. Big explosions aren’t required for purposes of the plot. Realize that a one-degree heading error, by the time it is discovered, will be too late to correct before a collision occurs. No massive takeovers are required. While not required for the plot, to make the idea more saleable to Hollywood, the Panama/Suez Canal attacks could spectacularly destroy a ship in the locks.

By knocking out a major US oil port and disrupting international shipping lanes, gasoline goes to $10-$15 per gallon in the US, the economy grinds to a halt, there are mass layoffs and mass shortages not just of oil but of food (no more lettuce from 3,000 miles away for Caesar Salads), and no more Nike’s from Indonesia.

Leading up to the attacks we learn about the characters. We hear various reports about the trade deficit, the hardship of high oil prices, and political posturing by impotent leaders. Our heroes are every day people, some with children, getting by as best they can. After the attacks, the shortages occur against a backdrop of incivility, gang violence, and vigilantism such that America rips itself apart. Some of our heroes don‚Äôt make through the first weeks. Those that do face apparently insurmountable obstacles

Oh, and like 9/11, one of the attacks fails. The Israelis thwart the Suez Canal plan.

Basically, recreate Montreal after the last big ice storm.

At the end of a run (and just before any have gone off), toss a couple of flares into nearby brush. Call 911 and report the fires, which will first draw in rescue workers, then power company workers.

While people are busy responding to the previous issue, drive to nearest generation facility / major substation, and use mortors (or for most of them, just throw sticks of dynamite) at the transformers. Adds a nice PCB/Oil fire, and the higher voltage parts are not easily replaced. For fun, lob a couple more at any exposed fuel lines.

Repeat with as many targets of opportunity as possible – but the key being to keep changing. E.g. 9-11 am focus on power lines, 11-12 focus on power generation, 12-1 random sniper fire while driving, 1-2 attack water supplies, small dams, 2-3 more sniper action, 3-4 toss a stick of dynamite into the local ER, 4-5 more sniper, 5-6 take over then destroy transmitting stations (e.g. first take over signal with fake broadcast about racial motiviation, or food contamination), then destroy key amplifiers or towers, etc.

Add in some suspense regarding they are all going to meet up for something really big later instead of being smart and going underground, so that the good guys can have a reason to chase, violate morals by torturing information out of some captured terrorists, and then the grand finale of avoiding the major radiation leak or whatever…

Plus, if you align all the attacks properly, they fit into the “24” show format nicely.

Joe Karsh ‚Ä¢ May 17, 2006 1:22 PM

The Continental Phased Array

The scene is Washington, DC. Unbeknownst to the general public, as a component of the domestic war on terror, the government‚Äôs Department of Homeland Security has mandated a significant improvement in the ability to locate cellular phones. The intent is to be able to accurately locate any operating cell phone instantly. The telecommunications industry has responded positively, as in the recent past. The capability to locate a handset, initially introduced to support 911 emergency services, has been enhanced with embedded GPS receivers. Cell phones are now able to determine and transmit their locations to the cellular system upon receipt of a specially coded request and without the user‚Äôs knowledge.

Because the DHS does not understand GPS, no one in the government realizes how accurate theses locations can be.

The scene is a terrorist Improvised Explosive Device R&D facility in the desert northwest of Baghdad. While studying ways to use cell phones as remote control detonators, terrorists have discovered the potential of the handset location capability. Employing Russian mathematicians, scientists and hackers, they develop new differential algorithms that can allow a cell phone to determine its location to a fraction of a cellular carrier wavelength and report, among other things, motion and orientation. Combined with a viral delivery system, all cell phones can now be infected with new programming that can silently turn on the carrier wave with good phase control. The ability to form a phased array beam is in place. The final demonstration of the R&D project shows the microwave-oven-like effect of a grid of cell phones mounted on a wall, when beamed at a suitable target.

The scene is Baghdad. It is the first field trial of the new terrorist radio weapon. The terrorists run a computer program that infects the cellular system, and then all of the handsets in the city. The program turns on all of the transmitters forming a beam that downs a Blackhawk helicopter. The software removes itself immediately afterward. The source and nature of the attack cannot be determined because each cell phone individually is considered harmless, even though many people suspect they can cause brain damage in the user.

They terrorists realize that the cellular carrier wave frequencies reside in the Water Hole, a range of frequencies at which the Earths atmosphere is transparent to electromagnetic transmissions.

The terrorists infect cellular systems throughout the world. The resulting beamforming capability can put 1,000,000,000 watts of electromagnetic energy on any target at sufficiently large distance. Using the North American and Indian phased arrays, they disable satellites in orbit around the Earth. Using city-sized arrays they damage aircraft, some of which crash due to control issues. Recall that we couldn‚Äôt use cell phones on airplanes until recently. This is an enormous disruption to the Western economies, with relatively minor effects in the less developed parts of the world. It takes a long time to figure out how this is happening.

Special Sci-Fi alternate ending:

The terrorists realize that a properly oriented subarray can transmit a polarized beam. With careful timing, good weather and the unwitting help of the astrophysical community, they point the beam at the sun, affecting the plasma dynamics and triggering solar flares. The timing is arranged to have the resulting solar storms hit the Earth when it is 12:00 noon in St. Louis, Missouri. The ensuing damage to the power transmission grid is devastating.

Alternate alternate:

Fortunately, heroic counterhackers discover the software infections and disrupt the beamforming signals and no beam results. Armed with knowledge of the nature of the exploit, the government is able to prevent its repetition.

Another Alternate Alternate:

The terrorists send a beam to every nearby star. 300 years later the aliens arrive, expecting the original senders to make good on their promises.

maximus ‚Ä¢ May 17, 2006 10:05 PM

maximum terror and economic destruction are different scenarios. the economic angle has already been covered quite well in the wall street CO scenario, and i hope that’s a candidate for your best plot. it’s very realistic and these localities of high infrasructure value are horribly exposed. no need to poison water supplies or taint oranges. just bomb the telecoms.

for maximum terror, the perps should target random and well-dispersed localities across the US, be time-coordinated, with some targets chosen for maximum population density, while others are chosen to bolster the belief that even smaller towns aren’t safe. don’t target anything under 5,000 people, since no one will really care. use all 30 perps in a thoroughly randomized matrix so that target patterning is difficult to establish. the point of this approach would be to cause ‘ordinary’ people (as differentiated from the ‘extraordinary’ ones in larger metro areas which get more news coverage usually) to first sympathize with the helpless victims, but quickly fear for their own safety and begin to change their daily routines. terror is about being so frightened for what might occur, that you radically alter your way of life.

i know on 9/11 i turned around and went home, not knowing if the large multinational i work for would be targeted. large-scale behavioral change is key. the terrorist approach should persist so long as the perps are alive and free to act, and should continue in random fashion, with similar modes of attack, such as shoe bombs, car bombs, etc. since bacterial or viral attacks are too far from the popular psyche to be ‘real’ enough. all attacks should be easily recognized as terrorist-originated, rather than random accidents.

despite the public’s general unfamiliarity with biological weapons, even a tiny bit of plutonium, however, properly dispersed, is astoundingly lethal, and would quickly waken an ignorant population to its vulnerability. this could be the coup de gr√¢ce or perhaps only the first attack.

at some point not far into this terror strategy, the government would likely enact martial law, which would further disrupt the newly unsettled masses.

bklynsmom ‚Ä¢ May 18, 2006 1:24 PM

For what it’s worth…(I just found your story request today)
Re: the terrorist movie plots

Check out a TV Movie-of-the-Week called “Under Siege” (no, not the one with Steven Seagal). It had a huge ensemble cast, including Hal Holbrook, Peter Strauss, E.G. Marshall, Paul Winfield, Lew Ayres, Thaao Penghlis, Stan Shaw, Barry Corbin, Lewis Grizzard, Fritz Weaver, Beatrice Straight and Victoria Tennant. It was filmed in 1985 (on a $3,000,000 budget) and shown on TV in early 1986. I was a crew member (and the only female driver). My job was mostly to chauffer the cast to and from sets in and around Little Rock. And Arkansas’ capitol “stood in” for the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C. Don Ohlmeyer was the Executive Producer and the screenplay was co-written by Bob Woodward (yes, from Watergate fame). Eerily, it was very close to what happened on 911, with the terrorists targeting U.S. cities. Having my hands used in the close-up (directed by Don Ohlmeyer himself while 2nd Unit was wrapping up final footage) to portray the female terrorist picking up and detonating the explosives at the military base was an unecpected perk for me. There was a lot of controversy in the newspapers before the movie was even shown; some thought it would cause too big of a backlash with the people who were being portrayed as the terrorists.
By the way, if you find a copy on VHS or DVD, I’d love to have one – all I have is what somebody taped on their VCR for me. I thought it was an awesome flick back then – even more so after 911. The film won an Emmy for Outstanding Sound.

Alice McGregor ‚Ä¢ May 22, 2006 6:02 PM

Here’s three, and both can be used in large (country- or world-wide) and small scales (city or building). At the end I will give an overview of a massive takeover plot, not truly practical for terrorists on a grand scale, but quite sufficient for, say, Manhattan Island, which was used previousally as a target.

  1. Rainmakers. (Pardon me for the silliness of this one.) Get 50 well trained rainmaker priests to call down the rain across the country or region. Flood the hell out of everything. It’s subtle (not attributable to terrorism), long lasting, and amazingly damaging for infrastructure and morale. Art Bell would say that this kind of plot is plausable, as he has done expieriments with his radioshow listeners which caused a similar style of event in a drought area. Cost: drums. Training: just gather existing priests.
  2. Hydrofluoric acid gas. Getting the components nessicary for hydrofluoric acid is easy. One way to get fluorine is by extraction from Teflon(TM) through burning. Released into the atmosphere after being forced through a pool of boiling water would give you large quantities of hydrofluoric acid, a colorless gass which is very, very deadly, and can even dissolve glass. This would kill millions in a nearly indetectible way. Acid rain comprised primarily of hydrofluoric acid would have the subtle effect of preventing the use of several import metal ions in the body, including calcium. This is most practical for installations/buildings with contained environmental systems, like high-rise buildings. 1 minute of 100 mg/cu. meter exposure is lethal, less material demands longer exposure, which should not be a problem in a corporate environment. Dissolving glass is useful in, say, military installations where there are separate, isolated environmental systems. Breaching of these systems is automatic with the acid. (10-minute exposure of a 100m x 100m x 100m office building – 1 million cubic meters – would require around 10KG of material.)
  3. EMPs. Powerful and simple directional EMP devices can be built for around $100-150 USD a pop (thick copper wire, plastic drums, electrolyte, and various base metals). They fit nicely into the back of even small pickup trucks (or old ones, so the cost of the transportation is cheap, too), and have a substantial range (a mile omnidirectional, ten in a directional cone, or more). These can be used to thuroughly disable important infrastructure like power generation, water sanitation, and essential services like hospitals, police, and firefighters.

The ultimate plan for terror and takeover would be a combination of several of these tactics – minus the rainmaker bit. Take a reasonably trained militia in squads of point attack, EMP truck drivers, and snipers, say 10 squads with 6 members, 8 EMP teams of four members, and half a dozen to a dozen snipers totalling up to 104 members, and place them just outside critical installations prior to T-0.

T-n, mine the roads of approach to the targets with spike strips and/or explosives to force approach on foot. T-30 have the snipers set up and used as advanced scouts. If there are protection measures in place (police at power generation facilities, for example), the snipers will eliminate them just as the EMP teams approach, T-2 or 3. At T-0, the EMPs are set off to disable power relay or generation facilties and facilties which contain their own power generation capability (like hospitals). As the power fails T+1, sweep in the teams to clean up police stations, fire stations, and hospitals, set charges, and run. The 4-man EMP teams would then enter their targets, T+5 to 10, and simply eliminate everyone to prevent those infrastructures from returning to operation, then set charges, and run. (The messier the power facility the better. Nuclear is a major, major target, and if the target, the team should have enough expertise to simply set it to meltdown, rather than use their own explosives.) Use the snipers to take out anyone approaching the original targets until T+120, pack up, and leave.

I could imagine the above being used on the television show 24. The most effective use would be to destroy the infrastructure of individual small towns at random across the US. This would instill the maximum amount of fear, and if it is truly random, impossible to predict. Can you tell I play far too much Tom Clancy and Counter-Strike? ;^)

Jeremy A ‚Ä¢ May 23, 2006 11:42 PM

This threat works on the premise that one pound of gasoline properly vaporised has the explosive power of roughly 1 pound of TNT.

The attack uses a fully loaded gasoline tanker driven through a road tunnel under a city. The objective is to collapse the tunnel and bring down overhead buildings.

Prior to the drive through a team disables the tunnel extractor fans to prevent dilution of the fuel air mix.
The team driving the tanker fit a high capacity pump with a spray head for efficient dispersal / evaporation. To lower the risk of premature ignition another team blocks the entrance(s) to the tunnel after the tanker enters. After an appropriate delay the tanker drives at a measured speed through the tunnel spraying the gasoline to achieve the best fuel/air mix. At the same time the tanker team drop multiple timer based igniter units set to flare at exactly the same time. To get more explosive power in a smaller space a second tanker containing LOX can drive through at the same time spraying liquid oxygen.

After completion of the run something like 80-100 tons of fuel and oxidiser is ready to explode in a few hundred yards of tunnel.

The effect depends on the depth of the tunnel. If possible the tunnel is selected to be very shallow and located under vulnerable buildings.

The effects of the attack are multiple

  1. Tunnel is damaged / destroyed.
  2. Overhead buildings are damaged / collapsed.
  3. Some in-tunnel fatalities – not the primary objective.
  4. Massive disruption to fuel distribution system afterwards – e.g. no tankers allowed in road tunnels.

Variations on this theme can include using disused railway tunnels and sewers.

el Fisico ‚Ä¢ May 24, 2006 8:31 AM

EMP has been mentioned several times, but I think this is new:

Given that airplane-travel since 9/11 has been given so much scrutinity and “safety enhancements”, a blow targeting commercial airtraffic would be highly effective psychologically, i.e. demoralizing.

An EMP “bomb” is rather easy to build: several high-voltage capacitors, a battery and high-voltage power supply to keep them fully charged, some wiring, the coil and a timed trigger, amounting to a few kilos. Note that none of the components are on any aircraft security “do-not-bring” list. Also, no chemical substances are used that might be sniffed by bomb-squad dogs.

The scenario goes: build a lot of these devices and sneak them aboard on a lot of airplanes nationwide at the same time. Have them go off at roughly the same time and watch those planes fall from the sky or at least experience severe technical troubles.

For maximum effect plan the distribution and triggers so that several aircraft approaching the same airport at the same time are affected, thus maximizing the trouble on the ground. Imagine the tower having to watch several planes go down because all runways are full.

And by distributing these incidents over a period of maybe one hour, media coverage and thus panic reactions can be maximized.

And you don’t even need suicide terrorists for it, AFAIK it is still possible to check in your suitcase and not go on board on inner-american flights. Such a suitcase will not be detected by explosive-sniffing dogs. X-ray might pose a problem, but it should be possible to camouflage the X-ray pictures. This is probably the weakest point.

Alternatively, shipping electronic components via airfreight shouldn’t arouse suspicion (no explosives!), so bringing down FedEx and UPS planes shouldn’t be a problem.

Note that EMP “bombs” probably won’t bring down the airplanes at once. Airplanes have to withstand lightning bolts that carry much more zest, so the main components are hardened. This is even benefical threat-wise. There is a good chance that the airplane cannot continue its normal flight route and will declare emergency, requesting immediate landing. Given the timing, several airplanes will report emergencies at the same time in the same place, overloading the emergency-handling capabilities in towers, control centers and airports.

big_swede ‚Ä¢ May 24, 2006 10:26 AM

I have a very simple scenario in mind that is partially covered by about five or six others, but I see it as a particularly interesting one so I’d like to offer my take on it. It targets a specific type of institution that seems to be universally (in the US at least) held as untouchable for moral reasons – the church. By “the church” I mean mainly the variants of christianity that I believe are most common – although let’s not rule out moslem churches either…

Anyway, the church is something most people have an important relation with and it seems a large part of the US population frequently go to church. That means that there are regularly a large congregation of civilians in one spot and thus should be a nice terrorist target.

Now assume the terrorists travel around in teams and randomly attack church buildings in different ways, defined by what would work for each particular church building:

  • Using (home-made) explosives to blow up the church during mass
  • Sniper attacks on people milling about outside after mass
  • Block doors and windows and set fire to wood/cloth if there’s a lot of combustible material (do you have churches built out of wood?)
  • Block doors and windows and let in carbondioxide (from a couple of stolen trucks perhaps?) or other poisonous gas.

Obviously the terrorists act as much as non-terrorists as they can to avoid suspicion, staying in place for quite a while (random lengths of time) before and after the actual attacks.

Churches have traditionally been the place where you can always find haven. The result of the attacks will be that people feel insecure in the place where they should feel most secure and any security measures, ludicrous or not, will likely be accepted by the general public;

  • Church-goers must register with their “home church”

  • Visits to other churches must be approved in advance

  • Airport-like screening measures will be introduced

  • Church money will go to improved surveillance of both church interiors and the perimeter (because it will be required by federal law) instead of helping those in need

  • Confession will no longer be secret, law will mandate that the priest records confessions if required by law enforcement agencies

Imagine the fear that would rise if this continues unstopped, a church full of people killed about once a month for several months – years! Oh, and to make it easier to point fingers in the wrong direction the terrorists might decide to blow up any type of church except, say, jewish churches. Wouldn’t that give the nazi sympathizers a boost to their ranks if they were savvy enough to use the opportunity for propaganda? And unsavvy enough to not realize they were being used as decoys…

By the way, the attacks would probably cause panic even if they only happened two or three times and the individual terrorist cells were caught immediately anyway.
